DOC.brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to assess the effect of a training of the inspiratory muscles against resistance at home during 10 weeks in multiple sclerosis patients with a severe disability.
DOC.brief_title: Fatigue and Inspiratory Muscles Training in Patients With Multiple Sclerosis
DOC.detailed_description: Patients will be informed about the study procedures during a follow-up consultation or an hospitalization in a Physical and Rehabilitation Medicine Unit. If they give their informed consent to participate in the study, an investigator will randomize them into one of the 2 arms of the study. This study consists of 3 visits. The first visit (inclusion) is planned at day 0, the second visit 10 weeks later and the third 3 months after day 0. A patient who is randomized in the experimental arm will have to follow 10 weeks of rehabilitation of the inspiratory muscles at home between first and second visit. During this period, investigators will call these patients once a week to assess the compliance with the rehabilitation. The patients who have been randomized in the control group will not follow this rehabilitation program.
DOC.criteria: Patient with remitting or progressive multiple sclerosis defined by McDonald criteria revised in 2005, with an EDSS between 6 and 7,5 Aged between 18 and 65 years Patients able to maintain the Powerbreathe Not to have had a flareup since at least 6 weeks Patients at least 4 weeks since a corticoid bolus Patients at least 6 weeks since a botulinum toxin injection Patients at least 4 weeks since a pulmonary infection Questionnaire EMIFSEP >= 55 Patients given their informed consent Patients who benefit or are affiliated to a social security regimen Patients with neurologic antecedents other that multiple sclerosis Patients with respiratory disorders other than those induced by multiple sclerosis Patients with orthopedic, cardiac, and rheumatologic invalidating antecedents Patients with comprehension or cognitive disorders impeding the realization of rehabilitation Pregnant women Patients under legal guardianship, or safeguard of justice Patients participating or planning participate within the 3 months of the study to another clinical research project
